item.title: How would you start?
item.dc:creator: @Java-RSPS-Noob Java-RSPS-Noob
item.description:
@Java-RSPS-Noob wrote:

  1. Buy a domain with real hosting for a webhost
  2. Make an actually nice website/forums, prevent bots from entering
  3. Before you publicly release literally do all skills etc extensively. This way you need to keep a “log” that all players can view to show that you as the owner have already took actions to find most bugs and are currently in the process of fixing them
  4. Start the server up after most of the bugs have been fixed and ask them to find ALL bugs you have missed no matter how big/small.
  5. Keep the bug log on forums/whatever updated at all times
  6. communication is KEY literally. Your players need to see that you ARE updating that you ARE fixing the bugs. That is how the server respect is earned!
  7. Develop new content. Try to keep content as frequent as possible but not too frequent cause that makes it look like it’s shabby work.
  8. Another point is to always remember to keep yourself happy.

Notes*

I didn’t want to include this in the main section here but this is VERY important.

The economy … if you let too many items get flooded at once you WILL fail!. Have money sinks, have item sinks, take items out of the stores, discontinue them, bring NEW items in temporarily. KEEP GAMBLING OUT. Make strict rules for the server about gambling/sharing, multi logging, muling, giving away items once a person quits, and etc.

Remember, they depend on YOU to design and keep the economy stable. They can provide suggestions yes, and I encourage them to provide suggestions. But it is YOU that must understand how an economy works and what is good/bad for it.

item.title: How would you start?
item.dc:creator: @rooneyscape rooneyscape
item.description:
@rooneyscape wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:2, topic:527433”]We can’t take our connections into consideration?

With this there isn’t much to think about. You set up a place for users to communicate with each other off game, you set up emails/contacts where they can get ahold of you to alert you about bugs and other issues, you obviously point the domain at your webhosting, you set up a few toplist pages and ask that your users vote for you, and that’s really it.

I don’t believe in forcing users to vote. I don’t believe that people should Pay-To-Win, I’d set up a ‘point’ system that is dependent on donations and also your playtime/forum activity. After I got the funds, I would contact my web developer friend to help me get on Rune-Server, google, and Moparscape through banner ads. I’d have adverts on each site, and I would try and generate hype with media showing how we compare to the ‘top’ servers on the serverlist.[/quote]

I never said you can’t take you’re own connections into consideration i just said you’ve got enough funds for the items listed above.

Good strategy though read it all.

item.title: How would you start?
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

We can’t take our connections into consideration?

With this there isn’t much to think about. You set up a place for users to communicate with each other off game, you set up emails/contacts where they can get ahold of you to alert you about bugs and other issues, you obviously point the domain at your webhosting, you set up a few toplist pages and ask that your users vote for you, and that’s really it.

I don’t believe in forcing users to vote. I don’t believe that people should Pay-To-Win, I’d set up a ‘point’ system that is dependent on donations and also your playtime/forum activity. After I got the funds, I would contact my web developer friend to help me get on Rune-Server, google, and Moparscape through banner ads. I’d have adverts on each site, and I would try and generate hype with media showing how we compare to the ‘top’ servers on the serverlist.

Ranting Below

Go look at the toplist servers. Thoughts that come to mind: Beyond awful. Horrid. Gross. Disgusting. Why do people play these? The competition is slim, what they have on people starting servers is that they are committed and good at advertising their piles of shit.

If you create something that connects with your intended audience, you will be successful. 2006scape did it, you can do it too. Not implying that was a well crafted server, but hell they did generate a lot of hype and created a unique experience.

Anyone can start a server. Anyone can add minimal features to make it above average. How successful your server will be also depends on your technology. You need a good balance of advertising, and unique content created by your technology.

Examples of technology are plugin systems, embedded web servers, dialogue systems, quest systems, etc
